Q1: Euler Equation

An agent faces the following optimization problem
max{ct}t=0∞E0∑t=0∞βtu(ct)(1)max_{\{c_t\}^\infty_{t=0}}E_0\sum^\infty_{t=0}\beta^tu(c_t) \tag{1}max{ct​}t=0∞​​E0​t=0∑∞​βtu(ct​)(1) subject to the budget constraint(s) where ctc_tct​ represents consumption and β\betaβ the discount rate. The interest rate is given by rrr. She owns initial asset level a0a_0a0​ and receives a stochastic income yty_tyt​ in each period. uuu satisfies the usual properties discussed in class.

  1. Set up the agent’s optimization problem.

Solution:

An infinitely lived consumer wants to maximize their expected lifetime utility from the consumption of a stream of goods ccc between periods t=0t=0t=0 and ∞\infty∞, as determined by the per-period utility function u(ct)u(c_t)u(ct​).

In each period ttt, they receive an income yty_tyt​, which they can either spend on a consumption good ctc_tct​, or save in the form of assets ata_tat​ that pay a constant interest rate rrr in the next period.

The utility of consumption in future periods is discounted at rate β\betaβ. It can take on values 0<β<10<\beta<10<β<1, where β\betaβ close to 000 means impatience (high discounting of future utility) and β\betaβ close to 111 means patience, i.e. similar utility derived from current and future consumption.

EtE_tEt​ denotes the expectation conditional on the information available in period ttt.

Then the agent’s problem is:
max{ct}t=0∞E0∑t=0∞βtu(ct)s.t. ct=yt+at−11+rat+1max_{\{c_t\}^\infty_{t=0}}E_0\sum^\infty_{t=0}\beta^tu(c_t)\\[0.5em]\text{s.t. } c_t=y_t+a_t-\frac{1}{1+r}a_{t+1}max{ct​}t=0∞​​E0​t=0∑∞​βtu(ct​)s.t. ct​=yt​+at​−1+r1​at+1​

  1. Derive the Euler equation using the following approaches:
    a) Substitution approach: use the per period budget constraint to substitute for ctc_tct​
    b) Lagrangian approach with per period budget constraint
    c) Lagrangian approach with lifetime budget constraint

Solution: a) substitution approach

Use
c1=y1+a1−11+ra2c_1=y_1+a_1-\frac{1}{1+r}a_{2}c1​=y1​+a1​−1+r1​a2​a1=(1+r)y0+(1+r)a0−(1+r)c0a_{1}=(1+r)y_0+(1+r)a_0-(1+r)c_0a1​=(1+r)y0​+(1+r)a0​−(1+r)c0​

The maximization problem when written out is:
max{ct}t=0∞E0∑t=0∞βtu(ct)=max{ct}t=0∞E0{1∗u(c0)+βu(c1)+...}max_{\{c_t\}^\infty_{t=0}}E_0\sum^\infty_{t=0}\beta^tu(c_t)=max_{\{c_t\}^\infty_{t=0}}E_0\left\{1*u(c_0)+\beta u(c_1)+...\right\}max{ct​}t=0∞​​E0​t=0∑∞​βtu(ct​)=max{ct​}t=0∞​​E0​{1∗u(c0​)+βu(c1​)+...}
Plug in a1a_1a1​ into c1c_1c1​:
c1=y1+[(1+r)y0+(1+r)a0−(1+r)c0]−11+ra2\begin{aligned}c_1&=y_1+\left[(1+r)y_0+(1+r)a_0-(1+r)c_0\right]-\frac{1}{1+r}a_2\\[0.5em]\end{aligned}c1​​=y1​+[(1+r)y0​+(1+r)a0​−(1+r)c0​]−1+r1​a2​​Plug this into the maximization problem:max{ct}t=0∞E0{1∗u(c0)+βu(y1+[(1+r)y0+(1+r)a0−(1+r)c0]−11+ra2)+...}max_{\{c_t\}^\infty_{t=0}}E_0\left\{1*u(c_0)+\beta u(y_1+\left[(1+r)y_0+(1+r)a_0-(1+r)c_0\right]-\frac{1}{1+r}a_2)+...\right\}max{ct​}t=0∞​​E0​{1∗u(c0​)+βu(y1​+[(1+r)y0​+(1+r)a0​−(1+r)c0​]−1+r1​a2​)+...}Take the derivative w.r.t. c0c_0c0​:

∂∂c0=u′(c0)+E0[βu′(y1+[(1+r)y0+(1+r)a0−(1+r)c0]−11+ra2)⏟=c1(−1)(1+r)]=0=u′(c0)+β(−1)(1+r)E0(u′(c1))=0\begin{aligned}\frac{\partial}{\partial c_0}&=u'(c_0)+E_0\left[\underbrace{\beta u'(y_1+\left[(1+r)y_0+(1+r)a_0-(1+r)c_0\right]-\frac{1}{1+r}a_2)}_{=c_1}(-1)(1+r)\right]=0\\[0.5em]&=u'(c_0)+\beta (-1)(1+r)E_0(u'(c_1))=0\end{aligned}∂c0​∂​​=u′(c0​)+E0​⎣⎢⎡​=c1​βu′(y1​+[(1+r)y0​+(1+r)a0​−(1+r)c0​]−1+r1​a2​)​​(−1)(1+r)⎦⎥⎤​=0=u′(c0​)+β(−1)(1+r)E0​(u′(c1​))=0​ Solving for u′(c0)u'(c_0)u′(c0​):u′(c0)=−(β(−1)(1+r)E0(u′(c1))u′(c0)=β(1+r)E0(u′(c1))‾‾\begin{aligned}u'(c_0)&=-(\beta(-1)(1+r)E_0(u'(c_1))\\[0.5em]u'(c_0)&=\underline{\underline{\beta(1+r)E_0(u'(c_1))}}\end{aligned}u′(c0​)u′(c0​)​=−(β(−1)(1+r)E0​(u′(c1​))=β(1+r)E0​(u′(c1​))​​​

Solution: b) Lagrangian with per-period budget constraint (BC)

The Lagrangian is (note: it does not matter whether you put βt\beta^tβt inside or outside the curly brackets!):L=Et∑t=0∞βt{u(ct)+λt[(1+r)(yt+at−ct)−at+1]}=Etβt(u(ct)+λt[(1+r)(yt+at−ct)−at+1])+Etβt+1(u(ct+1)+λt+1[(1+r)(yt+1+at+1−ct+1)−at+2])+...∂∂ct=Etβtu′(ct)+Etβtλt(1+r)(−1)=0∂∂at+1=βtλt(−1)+Etβt+1λt+1(1+r)=0∂∂λt=(1+r)(yt+at−ct)−at+1=0\begin{aligned}\mathscr{L}&=E_t\sum^\infty_{t=0} \beta^t\left\{u(c_t)+\lambda_t\left[(1+r)(y_t+a_t-c_t)-a_{t+1}\right]\right\}\\[2em]&=E_t\beta^t(u(c_t)+\lambda_t\left[(1+r)(y_t+a_t-c_t)-a_{t+1}\right])\\[0.5em]&+E_t\beta^{t+1}(u(c_{t+1})+\lambda_{t+1}[(1+r)(y_{t+1}+a_{t+1}-c_{t+1})-a_{t+2}])\\[0.5em]&+...\\[2em]\frac{\partial}{\partial c_t}&=E_t\beta^tu'(c_t)+E_t\beta^t\lambda_t(1+r)(-1)=0\\[0.5em]\frac{\partial}{\partial a_{t+1}}&=\beta^t\lambda_t(-1)+E_t\beta^{t+1}\lambda_{t+1}(1+r)=0\\[0.5em]\frac{\partial}{\partial \lambda_t}&=(1+r)(y_t+a_t-c_t)-a_{t+1}=0\end{aligned}L∂ct​∂​∂at+1​∂​∂λt​∂​​=Et​t=0∑∞​βt{u(ct​)+λt​[(1+r)(yt​+at​−ct​)−at+1​]}=Et​βt(u(ct​)+λt​[(1+r)(yt​+at​−ct​)−at+1​])+Et​βt+1(u(ct+1​)+λt+1​[(1+r)(yt+1​+at+1​−ct+1​)−at+2​])+...=Et​βtu′(ct​)+Et​βtλt​(1+r)(−1)=0=βtλt​(−1)+Et​βt+1λt+1​(1+r)=0=(1+r)(yt​+at​−ct​)−at+1​=0​
Solving the first FOC for λt\lambda_tλt​ (note that Etu′(ct)=u′(ct)E_tu'(c_t)=u'(c_t)Et​u′(ct​)=u′(ct​)): βtu′(ct)=βtλt(1+r)  ⟺  λt=u′(ct)1+r\beta^tu'(c_t)=\beta^t\lambda_t(1+r) \iff \lambda_t=\frac{u'(c_t)}{1+r}βtu′(ct​)=βtλt​(1+r)⟺λt​=1+ru′(ct​)​
One period forward (don’t forget expectation operator!): Etλt+1=Etu′(ct+1)1+r=11+rEtu′(ct+1)E_t\lambda_{t+1}=E_t\frac{u'(c_{t+1})}{1+r}=\frac{1}{1+r}E_tu'(c_{t+1})Et​λt+1​=Et​1+ru′(ct+1​)​=1+r1​Et​u′(ct+1​)

Plugging in λt\lambda_tλt​ and Etλt+1E_t\lambda_{t+1}Et​λt+1​ into the second FOC:βtλt(−1)+Etβt+1λt+1(1+r)=0λt=Etβt+1−tλt+1(1+r)λt=β(1+r)Etλt+1u′(ct)1+r=β(1+r)11+rEtu′(ct+1)u′(ct)1+r=βEtu′(ct+1)u′(ct)=β(1+r)E0u′(c1)‾‾\begin{aligned}\beta^t\lambda_t(-1)+E_t\beta^{t+1}\lambda_{t+1}(1+r)&=0\\[0.5em]\lambda_t&=E_t\beta^{t+1-t}\lambda_{t+1}(1+r)\\[0.5em]\lambda_t&=\beta(1+r)E_t\lambda_{t+1}\\[0.5em]\frac{u'(c_t)}{1+r}&=\beta(1+r)\frac{1}{1+r}E_tu'(c_{t+1})\\[0.5em]\frac{u'(c_t)}{1+r}&=\beta E_tu'(c_{t+1})\\[0.5em]u'(c_t)&=\underline{\underline{\beta (1+r)E_0u'(c_1)}}\end{aligned}βtλt​(−1)+Et​βt+1λt+1​(1+r)λt​λt​1+ru′(ct​)​1+ru′(ct​)​u′(ct​)​=0=Et​βt+1−tλt+1​(1+r)=β(1+r)Et​λt+1​=β(1+r)1+r1​Et​u′(ct+1​)=βEt​u′(ct+1​)=β(1+r)E0​u′(c1​)​​​

Solution: c) Lagrangian with intertemporal BC (IBC)

1. Derive lifetime budget constraint (IBC) from per-period BC:
ct=yt+at−11+rat+1at+1=(1+r)(yt−ct)+(1+r)at‾at+2=(1+r)(yt+1−ct+1)+(1+r)at+1at+3=(1+r)(yt+2−ct+2)+(1+r)at+2\begin{aligned}c_t&=y_t+a_t-\frac{1}{1+r}a_{t+1}\\[0.5em]a_{t+1}&=\underline{(1+r)(y_t-c_t)+(1+r)a_t}\\[0.5em]a_{t+2}&=(1+r)(y_{t+1}-c_{t+1})+(1+r)a_{t+1}\\[0.5em]a_{t+3}&=(1+r)(y_{t+2}-c_{t+2})+(1+r)a_{t+2}\end{aligned}ct​at+1​at+2​at+3​​=yt​+at​−1+r1​at+1​=(1+r)(yt​−ct​)+(1+r)at​​=(1+r)(yt+1​−ct+1​)+(1+r)at+1​=(1+r)(yt+2​−ct+2​)+(1+r)at+2​​
Substitute at+1a_{t+1}at+1​ into at+2a_{t+2}at+2​:
at+2=(1+r)(yt+1−ct+1)+(1+r)[(1+r)(yt−ct)+(1+r)at]=(1+r)(yt+1−ct+1)+(1+r)2(yt−ct)+(1+r)2at‾\begin{aligned}a_{t+2}&=(1+r)(y_{t+1}-c_{t+1})+(1+r)\left[(1+r)(y_t-c_t)+(1+r)a_t\right]\\[0.5em]&=\underline{(1+r)(y_{t+1}-c_{t+1})+(1+r)^2(y_t-c_t)+(1+r)^2a_t}\end{aligned}at+2​​=(1+r)(yt+1​−ct+1​)+(1+r)[(1+r)(yt​−ct​)+(1+r)at​]=(1+r)(yt+1​−ct+1​)+(1+r)2(yt​−ct​)+(1+r)2at​​​

Substitute this at+2a_{t+2}at+2​ into at+3a_{t+3}at+3​:at+3=(1+r)(yt+2−ct+2)++(1+r)[(1+r)(yt+1−ct+1)+(1+r)2(yt−ct)+(1+r)2at]=(1+r)(yt+2−ct+2)+(1+r)2(yt+1−ct+1)+(1+r)3(yt−ct)+(1+r)3at‾\begin{aligned}a_{t+3}&=(1+r)(y_{t+2}-c_{t+2})+\\[0.5em]&+(1+r)\left[(1+r)(y_{t+1}-c_{t+1})+(1+r)^2(y_t-c_t)+(1+r)^2a_t\right]\\[0.5em]&=\underline{(1+r)(y_{t+2}-c_{t+2})+(1+r)^2(y_{t+1}-c_{t+1})+(1+r)^3(y_t-c_t)+(1+r)^3a_t}\end{aligned}at+3​​=(1+r)(yt+2​−ct+2​)++(1+r)[(1+r)(yt+1​−ct+1​)+(1+r)2(yt​−ct​)+(1+r)2at​]=(1+r)(yt+2​−ct+2​)+(1+r)2(yt+1​−ct+1​)+(1+r)3(yt​−ct​)+(1+r)3at​​​

Now try to generalize the three underlined equations (again below for better visual):at+1=(1+r)(yt−ct)+(1+r)atat+2=(1+r)(yt+1−ct+1)+(1+r)2(yt−ct)+(1+r)2atat+3=(1+r)(yt+2−ct+2)+(1+r)2(yt+1−ct+1)+(1+r)3(yt−ct)+(1+r)3at...\begin{aligned}a_{t+1}&=(1+r)(y_t-c_t)&&+(1+r)a_t\\[0.5em]a_{t+2}&=(1+r)(y_{t+1}-c_{t+1})&+(1+r)^2(y_t-c_t)&+(1+r)^2a_t\\[0.5em]a_{t+3}&=(1+r)(y_{t+2}-c_{t+2})&+(1+r)^2(y_{t+1}-c_{t+1})+(1+r)^3(y_t-c_t)&+(1+r)^3a_t\\[0.5em]...\end{aligned}at+1​at+2​at+3​...​=(1+r)(yt​−ct​)=(1+r)(yt+1​−ct+1​)=(1+r)(yt+2​−ct+2​)​+(1+r)2(yt​−ct​)+(1+r)2(yt+1​−ct+1​)+(1+r)3(yt​−ct​)​+(1+r)at​+(1+r)2at​+(1+r)3at​​aT=[∑t=0T−1(1+r)T−t(yt−ct)]+(1+r)Ta0\begin{aligned}a_T&=\left[\sum^{T-1}_{t=0}(1+r)^{T-t}(y_t-c_t)\right]+(1+r)^Ta_0\end{aligned}aT​​=[t=0∑T−1​(1+r)T−t(yt​−ct​)]+(1+r)Ta0​​

Note: a0a_0a0​ instead of ata_tat​ because it is not in a summator, so it takes on no other values than ata_tat​ in the period we are in, which is period t=0t=0t=0.

Rewrite:

aT(1+r)T=a0+∑t=0T−1(1+r)T−t−T(yc−ct)aT(1+r)T=a0+∑t=0T−1(11+r)t(yt−ct)\begin{aligned}\frac{a_T}{(1+r)^T}&=a_0+\sum^{T-1}_{t=0}(1+r)^{T-t-T}(y_c-c_t)\\[0.5em]\frac{a_T}{(1+r)^T}&=a_0+\sum^{T-1}_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^t(y_t-c_t)\end{aligned}(1+r)TaT​​(1+r)TaT​​​=a0​+t=0∑T−1​(1+r)T−t−T(yc​−ct​)=a0​+t=0∑T−1​(1+r1​)t(yt​−ct​)​

Now let  T→∞\text{ }T\to\infty T→∞ and take care of uncertainty by adding expectations. aT(1+r)T=a0+E0∑t=0∞(11+r)t(yt−ct)\frac{a_T}{(1+r)^T}=a_0+E_0\sum^{\infty}_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^t(y_t-c_t)(1+r)TaT​​=a0​+E0​t=0∑∞​(1+r1​)t(yt​−ct​)

and note that the transversality condition applies: lim⁡t→∞(11+r)tAt=0\lim_{t\to\infty}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^tA_t=0t→∞lim​(1+r1​)tAt​=0

So aT(1+r)T=0\frac{a_T}{(1+r)^T}=0(1+r)TaT​​=0, and the equation becomes:0=a0+E0∑t=0∞(11+r)t(yt−ct)0=a_0+E_0\sum^{\infty}_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^t(y_t-c_t)0=a0​+E0​t=0∑∞​(1+r1​)t(yt​−ct​)

2. Derive Euler equation
L=E0∑t=0∞βtu(ct)+λ[a0+E0∑t=0∞(11+r)t(yt−ct)]\mathscr{L}=E_0\sum^\infty_{t=0}\beta^tu(c_t)+\lambda\left[a_0+E_0\sum^{\infty}_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^t(y_t-c_t)\right]L=E0​t=0∑∞​βtu(ct​)+λ[a0​+E0​t=0∑∞​(1+r1​)t(yt​−ct​)]

Note: no subscript on λ\lambdaλ, because ∞\infty∞!
∂∂ct=βtu′(ct)−(11+r)tλ=0∂∂λ=a0+E0∑t=0∞(11+r)t(yt−ct)=0\begin{aligned}\frac{\partial}{\partial c_t}&=\beta^tu'(c_t) -\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^t\lambda=0\\[0.5em]\frac{\partial}{\partial \lambda}&=a_0+E_0\sum^\infty_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^t(y_t-c_t)=0\end{aligned}∂ct​∂​∂λ∂​​=βtu′(ct​)−(1+r1​)tλ=0=a0​+E0​t=0∑∞​(1+r1​)t(yt​−ct​)=0​

Rearrange ∂∂ct\frac{\partial}{\partial c_t}∂ct​∂​ for λ\lambdaλ:βtu′(ct)=(11+r)tλ(11+r)−tβtu′(ct)=λ(1+r)tβtu′(ct)=λ\begin{aligned}\beta^tu'(c_t)&=\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^t\lambda\\[0.5em]\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^{-t}\beta^tu'(c_t)&=\lambda\\[1.5em](1+r)^t\beta^tu'(c_t)&=\lambda \end{aligned}βtu′(ct​)(1+r1​)−tβtu′(ct​)(1+r)tβtu′(ct​)​=(1+r1​)tλ=λ=λ​
Evaluate ∂∂ct\frac{\partial}{\partial c_t}∂ct​∂​ at t+1t+1t+1:(1+r)t+1E0βt+1u′(ct+1)=λ(1+r)^{t+1}E_0\beta^{t+1}u'(c_{t+1})=\lambda(1+r)t+1E0​βt+1u′(ct+1​)=λ

Set λ\lambdaλ's equal and rearrange for the Euler equation: (1+r)tβtu′(ct)=(1+r)t+1Etβt+1u′(ct+1)βtu′(ct)=(1+r)t+1−tEtβt+1u′(ct+1)u′(ct)=(1+r)Etβt+1−tu′(ct+1)u′(ct)=(1+r)βEtu′(ct+1)‾‾(1+r)^t\beta^tu'(c_t)=(1+r)^{t+1}E_t\beta^{t+1}u'(c_{t+1})\\[0.5em]\beta^tu'(c_t)=(1+r)^{t+1-t}E_t\beta^{t+1}u'(c_{t+1})\\[0.5em]u'(c_t)=(1+r)E_t\beta^{t+1-t}u'(c_{t+1})\\[0.5em]u'(c_t)=\underline{\underline{(1+r)\beta E_t u'(c_{t+1})}}(1+r)tβtu′(ct​)=(1+r)t+1Et​βt+1u′(ct+1​)βtu′(ct​)=(1+r)t+1−tEt​βt+1u′(ct+1​)u′(ct​)=(1+r)Et​βt+1−tu′(ct+1​)u′(ct​)=(1+r)βEt​u′(ct+1​)​​

  1. Provide an economic interpretation of the Euler equation.

Solution:

The Euler equation states that the consumer must be indifferent between consuming one more unit today (u′(ct)u'(c_t)u′(ct​)) and saving that unit and consuming it in the future (u′(ct+1)u'(c_{t+1})u′(ct+1​)).
If he consumes today, he gets the marginal utility of consumption today →u′(ct)\to u'(c_t)→u′(ct​).
If he saves that unit instead, he gets to consume (1+r)(1+r)(1+r) units in the future, each giving him u′(ct+1)u'(c_{t+1})u′(ct+1​) extra units of utility. Because this utility comes in the future it must be discounted by β\betaβ, where a β\betaβ close to zero implies impatience about the future and preference for present consumption, and a β\betaβ close to 1 implies patience, i.e. less discounting of future utility.

From Egor: If a consumer violates the Euler equation, say, consumes today more than she should have, she misses out on utility since additional units of consumption today will bring less utility than they could have provided they are saved and eaten tomorrow. Thus,the indifference of consumption conditioned by the Euler equation necessarily guarantees maximization of utility of consumption.

At optimum, the fact that the two sides must be equal guarantees that the consumer is indifferent about consuming today vs. in the future.

Rewriting, we can obtain a further interpretation: MUctMUct+1=MRS=u′(ct)βE0u′(ct+1)=(1+r)=MRT=MCctMCct+1\frac{MU_{c_t}}{MU_{c_{t+1}}}=MRS=\frac{u'(c_t)}{\beta E_0u'(c_{t+1})}=(1+r)=MRT=\frac{MC_{c_t}}{MC_{c_{t+1}}}MUct+1​​MUct​​​=MRS=βE0​u′(ct+1​)u′(ct​)​=(1+r)=MRT=MCct+1​​MCct​​​

  • the LHS is the marginal rate of substitution (MRSMRSMRS) between consumption today (ttt) and tomorrow (t+1t+1t+1),
  • the RHS is the relative price, the marginal rate of transformation (MRTMRTMRT) from saving between consumption today and tomorrow.
  • for r>0,MRT>1r>0, \enspace MRT >1r>0,MRT>1. This implies that the MRSMRSMRS must also be higher than one, which stems either from
    • β<1\beta <1β<1 and/or
    • differences in consumption levels in ttt and t+1t+1t+1
  1. From the Euler equation what can you say about the (actual and expected) consumption path when β(1+r)=1\beta(1+r)=1β(1+r)=1, β(1+r)>1\beta(1+r)>1β(1+r)>1 or β(1+r)<1\beta(1+r)<1β(1+r)<1 for each of the following cases?
    a) Constant income: yt=yy_t=yyt​=y, ∀t\forall t∀t
    b) uuu is quadratic and we are in the region where u′(c)>0u'(c)>0u′(c)>0

Solution: a) constant income = deterministic case

Euler equation: u′(ct)=(1+r)βEtu′(ct+1)u'(c_t)=(1+r)\beta E_t u'(c_{t+1})u′(ct​)=(1+r)βEt​u′(ct+1​)

  • β(1+r)=1\beta(1+r)=1β(1+r)=1: indifferent

    • u′(ct)=u′(ct+1)  ⟹  ct=ct+1u'(c_t)=u'(c_{t+1}) \enspace \implies \enspace c_t=c_{t+1}u′(ct​)=u′(ct+1​)⟹ct​=ct+1​

  • β(1+r)>1\beta(1+r)>1β(1+r)>1: very patient or high interest rate

    • u′(ct)>u′(ct+1)  ⟹  ct<ct+1u'(c_t)>u'(c_{t+1}) \enspace \implies \enspace c_t<c_{t+1}u′(ct​)>u′(ct+1​)⟹ct​<ct+1​
      • because: if u′(ct)>Eu′(ct+1)u'(c_t)>Eu'(c_{t+1})u′(ct​)>Eu′(ct+1​), then ctc_tct​ is smaller than E(ct+1)E(c_{t+1})E(ct+1​)
      • from Inada conditions:
        • u′>0→u'>0 \qquad \tou′>0→ additional utility = happier
        • u′′<0→u''<0 \qquad \tou′′<0→ utility gain at lower levels is higher, i.e. marginal gain of utility is decreasing

  • β(1+r)<1\beta(1+r)<1β(1+r)<1: very impatient or low interest rate

    • u′(ct)<u′(ct+1)  ⟹  ct>ct+1u'(c_t)<u'(c_{t+1}) \enspace \implies \enspace c_t>c_{t+1}u′(ct​)<u′(ct+1​)⟹ct​>ct+1​

Solution: b) uuu is quadratic and we are in region u′(c)>0u'(c)>0u′(c)>0

Quadratic utility: u(ct)=ct−α2Ct2u(c_t)=c_t-\frac{\alpha}{2}C_t^2u(ct​)=ct​−2α​Ct2​ with u′(ct)=1−αctu'(c_t)=1-\alpha c_tu′(ct​)=1−αct​

Plug into Euler equation:
u′(ct)=(1+r)βEtu′(ct+1)1−αct=β(1+r)Et[1−αct+1]1−αct=β(1+r)(1−α)Et(ct+1)ct=β(1+r)Et(ct+1)‾‾\begin{aligned}u'(c_t)&=(1+r)\beta E_t u'(c_{t+1})\\[0.5em]1-\alpha c_t=&\beta(1+r)E_t[1-\alpha c_{t+1}]\\[0.5em]1-\alpha c_t&=\beta(1+r)(1-\alpha)E_t(c_{t+1})\\[0.5em]c_t&=\underline{\underline{\beta(1+r)E_t(c_{t+1})}}\end{aligned}u′(ct​)1−αct​=1−αct​ct​​=(1+r)βEt​u′(ct+1​)β(1+r)Et​[1−αct+1​]=β(1+r)(1−α)Et​(ct+1​)=β(1+r)Et​(ct+1​)​​​

  • β(1+r)=1\beta(1+r)=1β(1+r)=1: indifferent

    • u′(ct)=Et(u′(ct+1))u'(c_t)=E_t(u'(c_{t+1}))u′(ct​)=Et​(u′(ct+1​))
        ⟹  \implies⟹ ct=Et(ct+1)c_t=E_t(c_{t+1})ct​=Et​(ct+1​)
        ⟹  \implies⟹ consumption follows a random walk

  • β(1+r)>1\beta(1+r)>1β(1+r)>1: very patient or high interest rate

    • u′(ct)>Et(ut+1′)u'(c_t)>E_t(u'_{t+1})u′(ct​)>Et​(ut+1′​) to fulfill the equality in Euler equation
        ⟹  \implies⟹ u(ct)<Et(ct+1)u(c_t)<E_t(c_{t+1})u(ct​)<Et​(ct+1​) from ct=β(1+r)Et(ct+1)c_t=\beta(1+r)E_t(c_{t+1})ct​=β(1+r)Et​(ct+1​) we have
        ⟹  \implies⟹ consumption profile is increasing in expectations

  • β(1+r)<1\beta(1+r)<1β(1+r)<1: very impatient or low interest rate

    • u′(ct)<Et((ct+1))u'(c_t)<E_t((c_{t+1}))u′(ct​)<Et​((ct+1​)) to fulfill the equality in Euler equation
        ⟹  \implies⟹ ct>Et(ct+1)c_t>E_t(c_{t+1})ct​>Et​(ct+1​)
        ⟹  \implies⟹ consumption profile is decreasing in expectations
  1. Suppose the agent observes an increase in the interest rate at period ttt. Does she increase her consumption in period t+1t+1t+1?

Solution:

Note:

  • The substitution effect is the change in consumption that results from the change in the relative price of consumption in the two periods. The increase in the interest rate makes future consumption relatively less expensive; this tends to make the consumer choose more consumption in the future and less consumption in the present.
  • The income effect is the change in consumption that results from the movement to a different indifference curve. The income effect is the change in the consumption of goods based on income. This means consumers will generally spend more if they experience an increase in income, and they may spend less if their income drops. If the consumer is a borrower, the increase in the interest rate makes the consumer worse off—that is, he or she cannot achieve as high an indifference curve. If consumption in each period is a normal good,this tends to reduce both ctc_tct​ and ct+1c_{t+1}ct+1​.

Regarding the question:

  • Total effect: depends on whether the consumer is a net lender or borrower
    • Substitution effect: r↑r \uparrowr↑, so saving becomes more attractive. ct↓c_t \downarrowct​↓ and ct+1↑c_{t+1} \uparrowct+1​↑
    • Income effect:
      • with no savings/debt: this consumer displays no income effect due to increase in the interest rate because he neither borrows nor lends money, so his income is not expected to change and hence he does not change his consumption pattern.
      • with positive wealth: if the consumer is a lender, i.e. he lends money in return for interest payments, he will expect an increase in income if r↑r\uparrowr↑, so he will consume more in the present and in the future: ct↑,ct+1↑c_t\uparrow, c_{t+1}\uparrowct​↑,ct+1​↑
      • with negative wealth: borrowing becomes more expensive. since this consumer is borrowing to spend, he will decrease consumption across the board: ct↓,ct+1↓c_t\downarrow, c_{t+1}\downarrowct​↓,ct+1​↓

SUMMARY

no debt lender borrower
substitution effect ct↓ct+1↑c_t\downarrow c_{t+1}\uparrowct​↓ct+1​↑ ct↓ct+1↑c_t\downarrow c_{t+1}\uparrowct​↓ct+1​↑ ct↓ct+1↑c_t\downarrow c_{t+1}\uparrowct​↓ct+1​↑
income effect ct−ct+1−c_t- c_{t+1}-ct​−ct+1​− ct↑ct+1↑c_t\uparrow c_{t+1}\uparrowct​↑ct+1​↑ ct↓ct+1↓c_t\downarrow c_{t+1}\downarrowct​↓ct+1​↓
total effect ct↓ct+1↑c_t\downarrow c_{t+1}\uparrowct​↓ct+1​↑ ct ? ct+1↑c_t \text{ ? } c_{t+1}\uparrowct​ ? ct+1​↑ ct↓ct+1 ? c_t\downarrow c_{t+1}\text{ ? }ct​↓ct+1​ ? 

Q2: Permanent Income Hypothesis

Assume a quadratic utility and β(1+r)=1\beta(1+r)=1β(1+r)=1. The optimal change in consumption between period ttt and period t−1t-1t−1 (from the perspective of period ttt) is given by Δct=r1+r∑i=0∞(1+r)−i(Et−Et−1)yt+i(2)\Delta c_t=\frac{r}{1+r}\sum^\infty_{i=0}(1+r)^{-i}(E_t-E_{t-1})y_{t+i}\tag{2}Δct​=1+rr​i=0∑∞​(1+r)−i(Et​−Et−1​)yt+i​(2)

  1. Suppose income follows the process given by yt=ρyt−1+ϵt with ρ∈(0,1), ϵt∼i.i.d. N(0,σ2)y_t=\rho y_{t-1}+\epsilon_t \text{ with } \rho\in(0,1), \text{ } \epsilon_t \sim \text{i.i.d. }N(0, \sigma^2)yt​=ρyt−1​+ϵt​ with ρ∈(0,1), ϵt​∼i.i.d. N(0,σ2) Derive the optimal consumption response Δct\Delta c_tΔct​. Interpret the resulting expression.

Solution:

i) First compute the expected income for each period from ttt onward from the perspective of t−1t-1t−1 and ttt

t−1t-1t−1
i=0Et−1(yt)=Et−1ρyt−1+Et−1ϵt=ρyt−1+0=ρyt−1i=1Et−1(yt+1)=Et−1ρyt+Et−1ϵt+1=Et−1ρ[ρyt−1]+0=ρ2yt−1i=2Et−1(yt+2)=Et−1ρyt+1+Et−1ϵt+2=ρ[ρ2yt−1]+0=ρ3yt−1...i=iEt−1(yt+i)=Et−1[ρyt+i−1+ϵt+i]=ρi+1yt−1\begin{aligned}\text{i=0} &\qquad E_{t-1}(y_t)=E_{t-1}\rho y_{t-1}+E_{t-1}\epsilon_t=\rho y_{t-1}+0&=\rho y_{t-1}\\\text{i=1} &\qquad E_{t-1}(y_{t+1})=E_{t-1}\rho y_{t}+E_{t-1}\epsilon_{t+1}=E_{t-1}\rho[\rho y_{t-1}]+0&=\rho^2y_{t-1}\\\text{i=2} &\qquad E_{t-1}(y_{t+2})=E_{t-1}\rho y_{t+1}+E_{t-1}\epsilon_{t+2}=\rho[\rho^2y_{t-1}]+0&=\rho^3y_{t-1}\\...\\\text{i=i} &\qquad E_{t-1}(y_{t+i})=E_{t-1}[\rho y_{t+i-1}+\epsilon_{t+i}]&=\rho^{i+1}y_{t-1}\end{aligned}i=0i=1i=2...i=i​Et−1​(yt​)=Et−1​ρyt−1​+Et−1​ϵt​=ρyt−1​+0Et−1​(yt+1​)=Et−1​ρyt​+Et−1​ϵt+1​=Et−1​ρ[ρyt−1​]+0Et−1​(yt+2​)=Et−1​ρyt+1​+Et−1​ϵt+2​=ρ[ρ2yt−1​]+0Et−1​(yt+i​)=Et−1​[ρyt+i−1​+ϵt+i​]​=ρyt−1​=ρ2yt−1​=ρ3yt−1​=ρi+1yt−1​​

ttt
i=0Et(yt)=Etρyt−1+Etϵt=ρyt−1+ϵti=1Et(yt+1)=Etρyt+Etϵt+1=ρ[ρyt−1+ϵt]+0=ρ2yt−1+ρϵti=2Et(yt+2)=Etρyt+1+Etϵt+2=ρ[ρ2yt−1+ρϵt]+0=ρ3yt−1+ρ2ϵt...i=iEt(yt+i)=Etρyt+i−1+Etϵt+i=ρi+1yt−1+ρiϵt\begin{aligned}\text{i=0} &\qquad E_{t}(y_t)=E_{t}\rho y_{t-1}+E_{t}\epsilon_t&=\rho y_{t-1}+\epsilon_t\\\text{i=1} &\qquad E_{t}(y_{t+1})=E_{t}\rho y_{t}+E_{t}\epsilon_{t+1}=\rho[\rho y_{t-1}+\epsilon_t]+0&=\rho^2y_{t-1}+\rho \epsilon_t\\\text{i=2} &\qquad E_{t}(y_{t+2})=E_{t}\rho y_{t+1}+E_{t}\epsilon_{t+2}=\rho[\rho^2y_{t-1}+\rho \epsilon_t]+0&=\rho^3y_{t-1}+\rho^2 \epsilon_t\\...\\\text{i=i} &\qquad E_t(y_{t+i})=E_t\rho y_{t+i-1}+E_t\epsilon_{t+i}&=\rho^{i+1}y_{t-1}+\rho^i\epsilon_t\end{aligned}i=0i=1i=2...i=i​Et​(yt​)=Et​ρyt−1​+Et​ϵt​Et​(yt+1​)=Et​ρyt​+Et​ϵt+1​=ρ[ρyt−1​+ϵt​]+0Et​(yt+2​)=Et​ρyt+1​+Et​ϵt+2​=ρ[ρ2yt−1​+ρϵt​]+0Et​(yt+i​)=Et​ρyt+i−1​+Et​ϵt+i​​=ρyt−1​+ϵt​=ρ2yt−1​+ρϵt​=ρ3yt−1​+ρ2ϵt​=ρi+1yt−1​+ρiϵt​​

ii) Plug these expressions in for Etyt+1E_ty_{t+1}Et​yt+1​ and Et−1yt+1E_{t-1}y_{t+1}Et−1​yt+1​ in Δct\Delta c_tΔct​

Δct=r1+r∑i=0∞(1+r)−i(Et−Et−1)yt+i=r1+r∑i=0∞(1+r)−i(Etyt+i−Et−1yt+i)=r1+r∑i=0∞(1+r)−i[(ρi+1yt−1+ρiϵt)−(ρi+1yt−1)]=r1+r∑i=0∞ρi(1+r)iϵt=r1+r∑i=0∞(ρ1+r)iϵt\begin{aligned}\Delta c_t&=\frac{r}{1+r}\sum^\infty_{i=0}(1+r)^{-i}(E_t-E_{t-1})y_{t+i}\\[1.5em]&=\frac{r}{1+r}\sum^\infty_{i=0}(1+r)^{-i}(E_ty_{t+i}-E_{t-1}y_{t+i})\\[1.5em]&=\frac{r}{1+r}\sum^\infty_{i=0}(1+r)^{-i}[(\rho^{i+1}y_{t-1}+\rho^i\epsilon_t)-(\rho^{i+1}y_{t-1})]\\[1.5em]&=\frac{r}{1+r}\sum^\infty_{i=0}\frac{\rho^i}{(1+r)^i}\epsilon_t=\frac{r}{1+r}\sum^\infty_{i=0}\left(\frac{\rho}{1+r}\right)^i\epsilon_t\end{aligned}Δct​​=1+rr​i=0∑∞​(1+r)−i(Et​−Et−1​)yt+i​=1+rr​i=0∑∞​(1+r)−i(Et​yt+i​−Et−1​yt+i​)=1+rr​i=0∑∞​(1+r)−i[(ρi+1yt−1​+ρiϵt​)−(ρi+1yt−1​)]=1+rr​i=0∑∞​(1+r)iρi​ϵt​=1+rr​i=0∑∞​(1+rρ​)iϵt​​

Remember convergence of an infinite geometric sequence: ∑t=0∞at=11−aif 0<a<1\sum^\infty_{t=0}a^t=\frac{1}{1-a}\qquad \text{if } 0<a<1t=0∑∞​at=1−a1​if 0<a<1
Since 0<ρ<1:0<\rho<1:0<ρ<1:
Δct=r1+r∑i=0∞(ρ1+r)iϵt=r1+r11−ρ1+rϵt=r1+r11+r1+r−ρ1+rϵt=r1+r1(1+r−ρ)1+rϵt=r1+r1+r1+r−ρϵt=r1+r−ρϵt\begin{aligned}\Delta c_t&=\frac{r}{1+r}\sum^\infty_{i=0}\left(\frac{\rho}{1+r}\right)^i\epsilon_t\\[1.5em]&=\frac{r}{1+r}\frac{1}{1-\frac{\rho}{1+r}}\epsilon_t\\[1.5em]&=\frac{r}{1+r}\frac{1}{\frac{1+r}{1+r}-\frac{\rho}{1+r}}\epsilon_t\\[1.5em]&=\frac{r}{1+r}\frac{1}{\frac{(1+r-\rho)}{1+r}}\epsilon_t=\frac{r}{1+r}\frac{1+r}{1+r-\rho}\epsilon_t\\[1.5em]&=\frac{r}{1+r-\rho}\epsilon_t\end{aligned}Δct​​=1+rr​i=0∑∞​(1+rρ​)iϵt​=1+rr​1−1+rρ​1​ϵt​=1+rr​1+r1+r​−1+rρ​1​ϵt​=1+rr​1+r(1+r−ρ)​1​ϵt​=1+rr​1+r−ρ1+r​ϵt​=1+r−ρr​ϵt​​

iii) Interpretation
From yt=ρyt−1+ϵty_t=\rho y_{t-1}+\epsilon_tyt​=ρyt−1​+ϵt​ we know that ρ\rhoρ is the persistence of past income (yt−1y_{t-1}yt−1​) in current income (yty_tyt​)

  ⟹  r1+r−ρ:\implies \frac{r}{1+r-\rho}:⟹1+r−ρr​: fraction of current income shocks that is consumed (call it multipliermultipliermultiplier of ϵt\epsilon_tϵt​ here)

  ⟹  \implies⟹ as ρ→0multiplier→r1+r\rho \to0 \qquad multiplier\to\frac{r}{1+r}ρ→0multiplier→1+rr​

  • where 0<r1+r<10<\frac{r}{1+r}<10<1+rr​<1 for positive interest rates
  • shocks are more transitory (your consumption response is low)

  ⟹  \implies⟹ as ρ→1\rho \to1ρ→1, multiplier→1\qquad multiplier \to 1multiplier→1

  • shocks are more persistent (your consumption response is high - a larger share of current income is consumed)
  1. Derive the volatility (variance) of income growth and that of consumption growth. Which is larger? Explain the result intuitively.

Solution:

Variance: expected value of squared deviation from the mean
Note that: Var(axt)=a2∗Var(xt)Var(ax_t)=a^2*Var(x_t)Var(axt​)=a2∗Var(xt​)

i) Variance of Δct\Delta c_tΔct​:
Var(Δct)=Var(r1+r−ρϵt)note that Var(axt)=a2∗Var(xt)=(r1+r−ρ)2∗σ2\begin{aligned}Var(\Delta c_t)&=Var\left(\frac{r}{1+r-\rho}\epsilon_t\right)\\[1.5em]&\text{note that }Var(ax_t)=a^2*Var(x_t)\\[0.5em]&=\left(\frac{r}{1+r-\rho}\right)^2*\sigma^2\end{aligned}Var(Δct​)​=Var(1+r−ρr​ϵt​)note that Var(axt​)=a2∗Var(xt​)=(1+r−ρr​)2∗σ2​

ii) Variance of Δyt\Delta y_tΔyt​:
From yt=ρyt−1+ϵty_t=\rho y_{t-1}+\epsilon_tyt​=ρyt−1​+ϵt​ we get:
yt−yt−1=ρyt−1+ϵt−yt−1Δyt=(ρ−1)yt−1+ϵt\begin{aligned}y_t-y_{t-1}&=\rho y_{t-1}+\epsilon_t-y_{t-1}\\[0.5em]\Delta y_t&=(\rho-1)y_{t-1}+\epsilon_t\end{aligned}yt​−yt−1​Δyt​​=ρyt−1​+ϵt​−yt−1​=(ρ−1)yt−1​+ϵt​​

Then the variance is:
Var(Δyt)=Var[(ρ−1)yt−1+ϵt]note that Var(axt)=a2∗Var(xt)=(ρ−1)2∗Var(yt−1)+Var(ϵt)=(ρ−1)2∗Var(yt−1)+σ2\begin{aligned}Var(\Delta y_t)&=Var[(\rho-1)y_{t-1}+\epsilon_t]\\[0.5em]&\text{note that }Var(ax_t)=a^2*Var(x_t)\\[0.5em]&=(\rho-1)^2*Var(y_{t-1})+Var(\epsilon_t)\\[0.5em]&=(\rho-1)^2*Var(y_{t-1})+\sigma^2\end{aligned}Var(Δyt​)​=Var[(ρ−1)yt−1​+ϵt​]note that Var(axt​)=a2∗Var(xt​)=(ρ−1)2∗Var(yt−1​)+Var(ϵt​)=(ρ−1)2∗Var(yt−1​)+σ2​

Because ρ<1\rho<1ρ<1 and hence the process is stationary, we know that the variance of yty_tyt​ is a constant, Var(yt)=V,∀ tVar(y_t)=V,\enspace\forall \text{ }tVar(yt​)=V,∀ t

Var(yt−1)=V=Var(ρyt−2+ϵt−1)=ρ2Var(yt−2)+Var(ϵt−1)=ρ2V+σ2V=σ21−ρ2\begin{aligned}Var(y_{t-1})=V&=Var(\rho y_{t-2}+\epsilon_{t-1})\\[0.5em]&=\rho^2Var(y_{t-2})+Var(\epsilon_{t-1})\\[0.5em]&=\rho^2V+\sigma^2\\[0.5em]V&=\frac{\sigma^2}{1-\rho^2}\end{aligned}Var(yt−1​)=VV​=Var(ρyt−2​+ϵt−1​)=ρ2Var(yt−2​)+Var(ϵt−1​)=ρ2V+σ2=1−ρ2σ2​​

Plugging this in for Var(yt−1)Var(y_{t-1})Var(yt−1​) in Var(Δyt)Var(\Delta y_t)Var(Δyt​):
Var(Δyt)=(1−ρ)2σ21−ρ2+σ2=(1−ρ)2σ21−ρ2+σ2(1−ρ2)1−ρ2=σ2−2ρσ2+ρ2σ2+σ2−ρ2σ21−ρ2=2σ2−2ρσ21−ρ2=2σ2(1−ρ)1−ρ2=2σ2(1−ρ)(1−ρ)(1+ρ)Var(Δyt)=2σ21+ρ\begin{aligned}Var(\Delta y_t)&=(1-\rho)^2\frac{\sigma^2}{1-\rho^2}+\sigma^2\\[1.5em]&=\frac{(1-\rho)^2\sigma^2}{1-\rho^2}+\frac{\sigma^2(1-\rho^2)}{1-\rho^2}\\[1.5em]&=\frac{\sigma^2-2\rho\sigma^2+\rho^2\sigma^2+\sigma^2-\rho^2\sigma^2}{1-\rho^2}\\[1.5em]&=\frac{2\sigma^2-2\rho\sigma^2}{1-\rho^2}\\[1.5em]&=\frac{2\sigma^2(1-\rho)}{1-\rho^2}\\[1.5em]&=\frac{2\sigma^2(1-\rho)}{(1-\rho)(1+\rho)}\\[1.5em]Var(\Delta y_t)&=\frac{2\sigma^2}{1+\rho}\end{aligned}Var(Δyt​)Var(Δyt​)​=(1−ρ)21−ρ2σ2​+σ2=1−ρ2(1−ρ)2σ2​+1−ρ2σ2(1−ρ2)​=1−ρ2σ2−2ρσ2+ρ2σ2+σ2−ρ2σ2​=1−ρ22σ2−2ρσ2​=1−ρ22σ2(1−ρ)​=(1−ρ)(1+ρ)2σ2(1−ρ)​=1+ρ2σ2​​

Which is larger, Var(Δct)Var(\Delta c_t)Var(Δct​) or Var(Δyt)Var(\Delta y_t)Var(Δyt​)? Explain the result intuitively.

Var(Δct)=(r1+r−ρ)2∗σ2Var(Δyt)=2σ21+ρ\begin{aligned}Var(\Delta c_t)&=\left(\frac{r}{1+r-\rho}\right)^2*\sigma^2\\[1.5em]Var(\Delta y_t)&=\frac{2\sigma^2}{1+\rho}\end{aligned}Var(Δct​)Var(Δyt​)​=(1+r−ρr​)2∗σ2=1+ρ2σ2​​

  • the volatility of consumption growth is smaller than the volatility of income growth since ρ∈(0,1)\rho \in(0,1)ρ∈(0,1)

  • the agent consumes less than the shock in period ttt and smooth consumption in response to the shock

  • Var(Δct)Var(\Delta c_t)Var(Δct​) is monotonically increasing in \rho, whereas Var(\Delta y_t) is monotonically decreasing in ρ\rhoρ

    • the difference approaches to zero as ρ→1\rho\to1ρ→1

  • income follows a random walk if ρ=1\rho=1ρ=1 and the consumption change mimics the income change (and thus has the same volatility) because shocks are fully permanent

  • Can you derive all the results below? Can you interpret the results using the arguments of persistent and transitory shocks? This will be a very good exercise for the exam:

yt=yt−1+ϵty_t=y_{t-1}+\epsilon_tyt​=yt−1​+ϵt​ Δct=ϵt\Delta c_t=\epsilon_tΔct​=ϵt​ Var(Δct)Var(\Delta c_t)Var(Δct​) = Var(Δyt)Var(\Delta y_t)Var(Δyt​)

Δyt=ρΔyt−1+ϵt\Delta y_t=\rho \Delta y_{t-1}+\epsilon_tΔyt​=ρΔyt−1​+ϵt​ with ρ∈(0.1)\rho \in (0. 1)ρ∈(0.1) Δct=1+r1+r−ρϵt\Delta c_t=\frac{1+r}{1+r-\rho}\epsilon_tΔct​=1+r−ρ1+r​ϵt​ Var(Δct)Var(\Delta c_t)Var(Δct​) > Var(Δyt)Var(\Delta y_t)Var(Δyt​)
yt=ϵty_t=\epsilon_tyt​=ϵt​ Δct=11+rϵt\Delta c_t=\frac{1}{1+r}\epsilon_tΔct​=1+r1​ϵt​ Var(Δct)Var(\Delta c_t)Var(Δct​) < Var(Δyt)Var(\Delta y_t)Var(Δyt​)
yt=ytP+ϵtytP=yt−1P+vtwhere ϵt,vt∽i.i.d. N(0.σ2),ϵt⊥vt\begin{aligned}y_t&=y^P_t+\epsilon_t\\y^P_t&=y^P_{t-1}+v_t\\&\text{where } \epsilon_t,v_t \backsim \text{i.i.d. } N(0. \sigma^2),\epsilon_t \perp v_t\end{aligned}yt​ytP​​=ytP​+ϵt​=yt−1P​+vt​where ϵt​,vt​∽i.i.d. N(0.σ2),ϵt​⊥vt​​ Δct=r1+r−ρϵt+vt\Delta c_t=\frac{r}{1+r-\rho}\epsilon_t+v_tΔct​=1+r−ρr​ϵt​+vt​ Var(Δct)Var(\Delta c_t)Var(Δct​) < Var(Δyt)Var(\Delta y_t)Var(Δyt​)

Q3: Certainty Equivalence

Assume the following quadratic utility function u(c)=c−12∗c2u(c)= c-\frac{1}{2}*c^2u(c)=c−21​∗c2 where ccc represents consumption.

  1. In class we argued that such a quadratic utility has the property of certainty equivalence. What does this mean? Explain in words.

Solution:

  • a quadratic utility function such as u(c)=c−12∗c2u(c)= c-\frac{1}{2}*c^2u(c)=c−21​∗c2 inhibits certainty equivalence
  • the derivative of u(c)u(c)u(c) is u′(c)=1−cu'(c)=1-cu′(c)=1−c, a linear marginal utility function
  • certainty equivalence means that an agent’s optimal actions are not affected by uncertainty, because his expected income is the same under certainty and uncertainty
  • this can be seen better in a graph:
  1. An agent has the utility above and lives for two periods only, t=0t=0t=0 and 111. At the end of his life, he leaves no bequest, i.e. a2=0a_2=0a2​=0. The agent solves {maxc0,c1,a1u(c0)+βE(u(c1))s.t.a1=(1+r)[a0+y0−c0]a2=(1+r)[a1+y1−c1]a2=0,a0 given\left\{ \begin{array}{lll} max_{c_0,c_1, a_1}u(c_0)+\beta E(u(c_1))\\[0.5em] \text{s.t.}\\ a_1=(1+r)[a_0+y_0-c_0] \\[0.5em] a_2=(1+r)[a_1+y_1-c_1] \\[0.5em] a_2=0, a_0 \text{ given}\end{array} \right.⎩⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎧​maxc0​,c1​,a1​​u(c0​)+βE(u(c1​))s.t.a1​=(1+r)[a0​+y0​−c0​]a2​=(1+r)[a1​+y1​−c1​]a2​=0,a0​ given​
    The expectation is taken for the future income, y1y_1y1​. Assume β(1+r)=1\beta(1+r)=1β(1+r)=1.

Calculate savings a1a_1a1​ in terms of income and initial assets for the following cases:
a) No certainty, i.e. income follows a deterministic time path y0=y0y_0=y_0y0​=y0​ and y1=y1y_1=y_1y1​=y1​.
b) Uncertainty about income from the perspective of period 000, but the expected income is the same as in a), i.e. E(y1)=y1E(y_1)=y_1E(y1​)=y1​.

Compare your results for these two cases and explain them in light of the certainty equivalence.

Solution:

i) solve constraints for ccc:
From constraint a1a_1a1​: c0=a0+y0−a11+rc_0=a_0+y_0-\frac{a_1}{1+r}c0​=a0​+y0​−1+ra1​​
From constraint a2a_2a2​: c1=a1+y1−a21+rc_1=a_1+y_1-\frac{a_2}{1+r}c1​=a1​+y1​−1+ra2​​
Since third constraint is a2=0a_2=0a2​=0: c1=a1+y1c_1=a_1+y_1c1​=a1​+y1​

ii) plug in for c0c_0c0​ and c1c_1c1​ in maximization problem:
max⁡a1u(c0)+βE(u(c1))=max⁡a1u(a0+y0−a11+r)+βEu(a1+y1)\max_{a_1}u(c_0)+\beta E(u(c_1))=\max_{a_1}u(a_0+y_0-\frac{a_1}{1+r})+\beta Eu(a_1+y_1)a1​max​u(c0​)+βE(u(c1​))=a1​max​u(a0​+y0​−1+ra1​​)+βEu(a1​+y1​)

iii) in this exercise we care about savings a1a_1a1​, so take FOC w.r.t. a1a_1a1​ and solve for a1a_1a1​:

FOC:
∂∂a1=−11+r∗u′(a0+y0−a11+r)+1∗βEu′(a1+y1)=0\frac{\partial}{\partial a_1}=-\frac{1}{1+r}*u'(a_0+y_0-\frac{a_1}{1+r})+1*\beta Eu'(a_1+y_1)=0∂a1​∂​=−1+r1​∗u′(a0​+y0​−1+ra1​​)+1∗βEu′(a1​+y1​)=0

Solving for a1a_1a1​:
−11+r∗u′(a0+y0−a11+r)+1∗βEu′(a1+y1)=0βEu′(a1+y1)=11+r∗u′(a0+y0−a11+r)\begin{aligned}-\frac{1}{1+r}*u'(a_0+y_0-\frac{a_1}{1+r})+1*\beta Eu'(a_1+y_1)&=0\\[1.5em]\beta Eu'(a_1+y_1)=\frac{1}{1+r}*u'(a_0+y_0-\frac{a_1}{1+r})\end{aligned}−1+r1​∗u′(a0​+y0​−1+ra1​​)+1∗βEu′(a1​+y1​)βEu′(a1​+y1​)=1+r1​∗u′(a0​+y0​−1+ra1​​)​=0​

since c0=a0+y0−a11+rc_0=a_0+y_0-\frac{a_1}{1+r}c0​=a0​+y0​−1+ra1​​ and c1=a1+y1c_1=a_1+y_1c1​=a1​+y1​, plug these in:
(1+r)βEu′(c1)=u′(c0)(1+r)\beta Eu'(c_1)=u'(c_0)(1+r)βEu′(c1​)=u′(c0​)

by definition of the exercise u(c)=c−12∗c2u(c)= c-\frac{1}{2}*c^2u(c)=c−21​∗c2, the derivative is u′(c)=1−cu'(c)=1-cu′(c)=1−c. plug this in also:
(1+r)βE(1−c1)=1−c0(1+r)\beta E(1-c_1)=1-c_0(1+r)βE(1−c1​)=1−c0​

and now we got rid of the general derivative expression. now we can plug in the values for c0c_0c0​ and c1c_1c1​ again: c0=a0+y0−a11+rc_0=a_0+y_0-\frac{a_1}{1+r}c0​=a0​+y0​−1+ra1​​ and c1=a1+y1c_1=a_1+y_1c1​=a1​+y1​:

(1+r)βE(1−(a1+y1))=1−(a0+y0−a11+r)(1+r)\beta E(1-(a_1+y_1))=1-(a_0+y_0-\frac{a_1}{1+r})(1+r)βE(1−(a1​+y1​))=1−(a0​+y0​−1+ra1​​)

by definition of the exercise, (1+r)β=1(1+r)\beta=1(1+r)β=1, so:
1∗E(1−(a1+y1))=1−(a0+y0−a11+r)1*E(1-(a_1+y_1))=1-(a_0+y_0-\frac{a_1}{1+r})1∗E(1−(a1​+y1​))=1−(a0​+y0​−1+ra1​​)
finally you can solve for a1a_1a1​:

E(1)−E(a1)−E(y1)=1−a0−y0+a11+rE(1)-E(a_1)-E(y_1)=1-a_0-y_0+\frac{a_1}{1+r}E(1)−E(a1​)−E(y1​)=1−a0​−y0​+1+ra1​​

from the first constraint we know that a1=(1+r)[a0+y0−c0]a_1=(1+r)[a_0+y_0-c_0]a1​=(1+r)[a0​+y0​−c0​], in other words: a1a_1a1​ only depends on things in period t=0t=0t=0, so E(a1)=a1E(a_1)=a_1E(a1​)=a1​!

E(1)−a1−E(y1)=1−a0−y0+a11+r1−E(y1)+a0+y0=1+a11+r+a1−E(y1)+a0+y0=a11+r+a1(1+r)(a0+y0−E(y1))=a1+a1(1+r)=a1(2+r)(1+r)(a0+y0−E(y1))2+r=a1\begin{aligned} E(1)-a_1-E(y_1)&=1-a_0-y_0+\frac{a_1}{1+r}\\[1.5em]1-E(y_1)+a_0+y_0&=1+\frac{a_1}{1+r}+a_1 \\[1.5em]-E(y_1)+a_0+y_0&=\frac{a_1}{1+r}+a_1\\[1.5em](1+r)(a_0+y_0-E(y_1))&=a_1+a_1(1+r)=a_1(2+r)\\[1.5em]\frac{(1+r)(a_0+y_0-E(y_1))}{2+r}&=a_1\end{aligned}E(1)−a1​−E(y1​)1−E(y1​)+a0​+y0​−E(y1​)+a0​+y0​(1+r)(a0​+y0​−E(y1​))2+r(1+r)(a0​+y0​−E(y1​))​​=1−a0​−y0​+1+ra1​​=1+1+ra1​​+a1​=1+ra1​​+a1​=a1​+a1​(1+r)=a1​(2+r)=a1​​

Rewrite this a bit: always put a 1+r1+r1+r into the denominator

a1=(1+r)(a0+y0−E(y1))2+r=(2+r1+r)−1a0+y0−E(y1)\begin{aligned}a_1&=\frac{(1+r)(a_0+y_0-E(y_1))}{2+r}=\left(\frac{2+r}{1+r}\right)^{-1}a_0+y_0-E(y_1)\end{aligned}a1​​=2+r(1+r)(a0​+y0​−E(y1​))​=(1+r2+r​)−1a0​+y0​−E(y1​)​

then the fraction becomes:
(2+r1+r)−1=(1+r1+r+11+r)−1=(1+11+r)−1\begin{aligned}\left(\frac{2+r}{1+r}\right)^{-1}=\left(\frac{1+r}{1+r}+\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^{-1}=\left(1+\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^{-1}\end{aligned}(1+r2+r​)−1=(1+r1+r​+1+r1​)−1=(1+1+r1​)−1​

so finally a1a_1a1​ becomes:
a1=(1+11+r)−1(a0+y0−E(y1))a_1=\left(1+\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^{-1}(a_0+y_0-E(y_1))a1​=(1+1+r1​)−1(a0​+y0​−E(y1​))

Case a): No certainty, i.e. income follows a deterministic time path y0=y0y_0=y_0y0​=y0​ and y1=y1y_1=y_1y1​=y1​.

Solution:

Then a1a_1a1​ becomes:
a1=(1+11+r)−1(a0+y0−y1)a_1=\left(1+\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^{-1}(a_0+y_0-y_1)a1​=(1+1+r1​)−1(a0​+y0​−y1​)

Case b): Uncertainty about income from the perspective of period 000, but the expected income is the same as in a), i.e. E(y1)=y1E(y_1)=y_1E(y1​)=y1​.

Solution:

Then a1a_1a1​ becomes:
a1=(1+11+r)−1(a0+y0−y1)a_1=\left(1+\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^{-1}(a_0+y_0-y_1)a1​=(1+1+r1​)−1(a0​+y0​−y1​)

Compare your results for these two cases and explain them in light of the certainty equivalence.

The consumer shows Certainty Equivalence: uncertainty does not affect his optimal actions.

However, consumption and utility will not stay unchanged: consumption at time t=1t=1t=1 will be different, utility will be different as well.

Q4: Optimal Taxation

A representative consumer solves max{Ct}t=0∞E0∑t=0∞βt[Ct−α2Ct2]s.t. At+1=(1+r)[At+Yt−(1+τtC)Ct−Tt],A0 givenmax_{\{C_t\}^\infty_{t=0}}E_0\sum^\infty_{t=0}\beta^t\left[C_t-\frac{\alpha}{2}C_t^2\right]\\[0.5em] \text{s.t. } A_{t+1}=(1+r)[A_t+Y_t-(1+\tau^C_t)C_t-T_t], \\[0.5em]A_0 \text{ given}max{Ct​}t=0∞​​E0​t=0∑∞​βt[Ct​−2α​Ct2​]s.t. At+1​=(1+r)[At​+Yt​−(1+τtC​)Ct​−Tt​],A0​ given He can save and borrow at the risk-free rate rrr and receives a stochastic income YtY_tYt​ in each period. The government levies a consumption tax τC\tau^CτC and a lump sum tax TTT.

Suppose the government has to finance a stream of expenditures, {Gt}t=0∞={Gˉ,G‾,Gˉ,G‾,...}\left\{G_t\right\}^\infty_{t=0}=\left\{\bar{G},\underline{G},\bar{G},\underline{G},...\right\}{Gt​}t=0∞​={Gˉ,G​,Gˉ,G​,...} where Gˉ>G‾>0\bar{G}>\underline{G}>0Gˉ>G​>0. The government budget has to be balanced in every period, because it is not possible for the government to issue debt.

  1. Consider the following possibilities for financing GGG's:
    • A positive lump sum tax (Tt>0T_t>0Tt​>0) and no consumption tax (τtC=0\tau^C_t=0τtC​=0, such that the government budget constraint is given by: Gt=TtG_t=T_tGt​=Tt​.
    • A positive consumption tax (τtC>0\tau^C_t>0τtC​>0) and no lump sum tax (Tt=0T_t=0Tt​=0), such that the government budget constraint is given by: Gt=τtCCtG_t=\tau^C_tC_tGt​=τtC​Ct​.

Derive the Euler equation for each case. Are those policies distortionary for the savings decision? Why/ why not?

Solution:

max{Ct}t=0∞E0∑t=0∞βt[Ct−α2Ct2]s.t. At+1=(1+r)[At+Yt−(1+τtC)Ct−Tt]max_{\{C_t\}^\infty_{t=0}}E_0\sum^\infty_{t=0}\beta^t\left[C_t-\frac{\alpha}{2}C_t^2\right]\\[0.5em] \text{s.t. } A_{t+1}=(1+r)[A_t+Y_t-(1+\tau^C_t)C_t-T_t]max{Ct​}t=0∞​​E0​t=0∑∞​βt[Ct​−2α​Ct2​]s.t. At+1​=(1+r)[At​+Yt​−(1+τtC​)Ct​−Tt​]

Lagrangian:L=Et∑t=0∞βt{[Ct−α2Ct2]+λt[(1+r)[At+Yt−(1+τtC)Ct−Tt]−At+1]}=βt{[Ct−α2Ct2]+λt[(1+r)[At+Yt−(1+τtC)Ct−Tt]−At+1]}+Etβt+1{[Ct+1−α2Ct+12]+λt+1[(1+r)[At+1+Yt+1−(1+τt+1C)Ct+1−Tt+1]−At+2]}+...∂L∂Ct=βt(1−αCt)+βtλt(1+r)(−1)(1+τtC)=0∂L∂Ct+1=Etβt+1(1−αCt+1)+Etβt+1λt+1(1+r)(−1)(1+τt+1C)=0∂L∂At+1=βtλt(−1)+Etβt+1λt+1(1+r)=0\begin{aligned}\mathscr{L}&=E_t\sum^\infty_{t=0}\beta^t\left\{\left[C_t-\frac{\alpha}{2}C_t^2\right]+\lambda_t\left[(1+r)[A_t+Y_t-(1+\tau^C_t)C_t-T_t]-A_{t+1}\right]\right\}\\[0.5em]&=\beta^t\left\{\left[C_t-\frac{\alpha}{2}C_t^2\right]+\lambda_t\left[(1+r)[A_t+Y_t-(1+\tau^C_t)C_t-T_t]-A_{t+1}\right]\right\}\\[0.5em]&+E_t\beta^{t+1}\left\{\left[C_{t+1}-\frac{\alpha}{2}C^2_{t+1}\right]+\lambda_{t+1}\left[(1+r)[A_{t+1}+Y_{t+1}-(1+\tau^C_{t+1})C_{t+1}-T_{t+1}]-A_{t+2}\right]\right\}\\[0.5em]&+...\\[1.5em]\frac{\partial\mathscr{L}}{\partial C_t}&=\beta^t(1-\alpha C_t)+\beta^t\lambda_t(1+r)(-1)(1+\tau^C_t)=0\\[1.5em]\frac{\partial\mathscr{L}}{\partial C_{t+1}}&=E_t\beta^{t+1}(1-\alpha C_{t+1})+E_t\beta^{t+1}\lambda_{t+1}(1+r)(-1)(1+\tau^C_{t+1})=0\\[1.5em]\frac{\partial\mathscr{L}}{\partial A_{t+1}}&=\beta^t\lambda_t(-1)+E_t\beta^{t+1}\lambda_{t+1}(1+r)=0\end{aligned}L∂Ct​∂L​∂Ct+1​∂L​∂At+1​∂L​​=Et​t=0∑∞​βt{[Ct​−2α​Ct2​]+λt​[(1+r)[At​+Yt​−(1+τtC​)Ct​−Tt​]−At+1​]}=βt{[Ct​−2α​Ct2​]+λt​[(1+r)[At​+Yt​−(1+τtC​)Ct​−Tt​]−At+1​]}+Et​βt+1{[Ct+1​−2α​Ct+12​]+λt+1​[(1+r)[At+1​+Yt+1​−(1+τt+1C​)Ct+1​−Tt+1​]−At+2​]}+...=βt(1−αCt​)+βtλt​(1+r)(−1)(1+τtC​)=0=Et​βt+1(1−αCt+1​)+Et​βt+1λt+1​(1+r)(−1)(1+τt+1C​)=0=βtλt​(−1)+Et​βt+1λt+1​(1+r)=0​

Rearrange FOC3 for Etλt+1E_t\lambda_{t+1}Et​λt+1​: Etβt+1λt+1=βtλt1+rEtλt+1=βt−t−1λt1+rEtλt+1=β−1λt1+r\begin{aligned}E_t\beta^{t+1}\lambda_{t+1}&=\beta^{t}\frac{\lambda_t}{1+r}\\[0.5em]E_t\lambda_{t+1}&=\beta^{t-t-1}\frac{\lambda_t}{1+r}\\[0.5em]E_t\lambda_{t+1}&=\beta^{-1}\frac{\lambda_t}{1+r}\end{aligned}Et​βt+1λt+1​Et​λt+1​Et​λt+1​​=βt1+rλt​​=βt−t−11+rλt​​=β−11+rλt​​​

Plug this into Etλt+1E_t\lambda_{t+1}Et​λt+1​ in FOC2 and rearrange for λt\lambda_tλt​: Etβt+1(1−αCt+1)=Etβt+1λt+1(1+r)(1+τt+1C)Etβt+1(1−αCt+1)=βt+1(β−1λt1+r)(1+r)(1+τt+1C)Et(1−αCt+1)=β−1λt1+r(1+r)(1+τt+1C)Et(1−αCt+1)=β−1λt(1+τt+1C)βEt(1−αCt+1)1+τt+1C=λt\begin{aligned}E_t\beta^{t+1}(1-\alpha C_{t+1})&=E_t\beta^{t+1}\lambda_{t+1}(1+r)(1+\tau^C_{t+1})\\[0.5em]E_t\beta^{t+1}(1-\alpha C_{t+1})&=\beta^{t+1}\left(\beta^{-1}\frac{\lambda_t}{1+r}\right)(1+r)(1+\tau^C_{t+1})\\[.5em]E_t(1-\alpha C_{t+1})&=\beta^{-1}\frac{\lambda_t}{1+r}(1+r)(1+\tau^C_{t+1})\\[1.5em]E_t(1-\alpha C_{t+1})&=\beta^{-1}\lambda_t(1+\tau^C_{t+1})\\[1.5em]\frac{\beta E_t(1-\alpha C_{t+1})}{1+\tau^C_{t+1}}&=\lambda_t\end{aligned}Et​βt+1(1−αCt+1​)Et​βt+1(1−αCt+1​)Et​(1−αCt+1​)Et​(1−αCt+1​)1+τt+1C​βEt​(1−αCt+1​)​​=Et​βt+1λt+1​(1+r)(1+τt+1C​)=βt+1(β−11+rλt​​)(1+r)(1+τt+1C​)=β−11+rλt​​(1+r)(1+τt+1C​)=β−1λt​(1+τt+1C​)=λt​​

Plug this into λt\lambda_tλt​ in FOC1: βt(1−αCt)=βtλt(1+r)(1+τtC)βt(1−αCt)=βt(βEt(1−αCt+1)1+τt+1C)(1+r)(1+τtC)1−αCt1+τtC=β(1−α)Et(Ct+1)1+τt+1C(1+r)\begin{aligned}\beta^t(1-\alpha C_t)&=\beta^t\lambda_t(1+r)(1+\tau^C_t)\\[1.5em]\beta^t(1-\alpha C_t)&=\beta^t\left(\frac{\beta E_t(1-\alpha C_{t+1})}{1+\tau^C_{t+1}}\right)(1+r)(1+\tau^C_t)\\[1.5em]\frac{1-\alpha C_t}{1+\tau^C_t}&=\beta(1-\alpha)\frac{E_t(C_{t+1})}{1+\tau^C_{t+1}}(1+r)\end{aligned}βt(1−αCt​)βt(1−αCt​)1+τtC​1−αCt​​​=βtλt​(1+r)(1+τtC​)=βt(1+τt+1C​βEt​(1−αCt+1​)​)(1+r)(1+τtC​)=β(1−α)1+τt+1C​Et​(Ct+1​)​(1+r)​

a) positive lump sum tax (Tt>0T_t>0Tt​>0) and no consumption tax (τtC=0\tau^C_t=0τtC​=0), such that the government budget constraint is given by: Gt=TtG_t=T_tGt​=Tt​. Is it distortionary?

Lump sum tax Euler equation:
1−αCt1+0=β(1−α)Et(Ct+1)1+0(1+r)1−αCt=β(1−α)Et(Ct+1)\begin{aligned}\frac{1-\alpha C_t}{1+0}&=\beta(1-\alpha)\frac{E_t(C_{t+1})}{1+0}(1+r)\\[1.5em]1-\alpha C_t&=\beta (1-\alpha)E_t(C_{t+1})\end{aligned}1+01−αCt​​1−αCt​​=β(1−α)1+0Et​(Ct+1​)​(1+r)=β(1−α)Et​(Ct+1​)​

The lump sum tax is not distortionary, the Euler equation is equivalent to the base case.

b) positive consumption tax (τtC>0\tau^C_t>0τtC​>0) and no lump sum tax (Tt=0T_t=0Tt​=0), such that the government budget constraint is given by: Gt=τtCCtG_t=\tau^C_tC_tGt​=τtC​Ct​. Distortionary?

Consumption tax Euler equation:
1−αCt1+τtC=β(1−α)Et(Ct+1)1+τt+1C(1+r)\frac{1-\alpha C_t}{1+\tau^C_t}=\beta(1-\alpha)\frac{E_t(C_{t+1})}{1+\tau^C_{t+1}}(1+r)1+τtC​1−αCt​​=β(1−α)1+τt+1C​Et​(Ct+1​)​(1+r)

The consumption tax is not distortionary if τtC=τt+1C\tau^C_t =\tau^C_{t+1}τtC​=τt+1C​, because one can just multiply by (1+τ)(1+\tau)(1+τ) and the tax effect cancels out. But this is unrealistic.
More realistically, because government expenditure varies over time, through Gt=τtCCt, τcG_t=\tau^C_tC_t, \text{ } \tau^cGt​=τtC​Ct​, τc will vary over time. The tax is distortionary, if τtC≠τt+1C\tau^C_t \ne\tau^C_{t+1}τtC​​=τt+1C​, which is the realistic case.

Note: distortionary means that consumption ratio between periods changes, i.e. if it distorts the consumer’s consumption preferences between periods. A simple change in one period does not make a tax distortionary.

  1. Suppose the government cannot levy lump sum taxes (Tt=0T_t=0Tt​=0) but can issue government debt. The government budget constraint is given by: Gt+(1+r)Bt=Bt+1+τtCCtG_t+(1+r)B_t=B_{t+1}+\tau^C_tC_tGt​+(1+r)Bt​=Bt+1​+τtC​Ct​. For simplicity set B0=0B_0=0B0​=0, Furthermore assume that the government has to pay back all liabilities in the limit, so lim⁡T→∞BT=0\lim_{T\to\infty}B_T=0limT→∞​BT​=0. Derive the positive consumption tax that does not distort the savings decision.

Solution:

i) Derive intertemporal government BC. Note that τtC=τC\tau^C_t=\tau^CτtC​=τC. The tax is constant over time, because the tax should be non-distortionary.
B0=11+r(B1+τcC0−G0)B_0=\frac{1}{1+r}(B_1+\tau^cC_0-G_0)B0​=1+r1​(B1​+τcC0​−G0​)

Plug in B1=11+r(B2+τcC1−G1)B_1=\frac{1}{1+r}(B_2+\tau^cC_1-G_1)B1​=1+r1​(B2​+τcC1​−G1​):

Plug in B2=(11+r(B3+τcC2−G2))B_2=\left(\frac{1}{1+r}(B_3+\tau^cC_2-G_2)\right)B2​=(1+r1​(B3​+τcC2​−G2​)):

B0=11+r[11+r(B2+τcC1−G1)+τcC0−G0]B0=11+r[11+r((11+r(B3+τcC2−G2))+τcC1−G1)+τcC0−G0]B0=(11+r)3(B3+τCC2−G2)+(11+r)2(τCC1−G1)+(11+r)1(τCC0−G0)B0=(11+r)3B3+(11+r)3(τCC2−G2)+(11+r)2(τCC1−G1)+(11+r)1(τCC0−G0)\begin{aligned}B_0&=\frac{1}{1+r}\left[\frac{1}{1+r}(B_2+\tau^cC_1-G_1)+\tau^cC_0-G_0\right]\\[1.5em]B_0&=\frac{1}{1+r}\left[\frac{1}{1+r}\left(\left(\frac{1}{1+r}(B_3+\tau^cC_2-G_2\right)\right)+\tau^cC_1-G_1)+\tau^cC_0-G_0\right]\\[1.5em]B_0&=\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^3(B_3+\tau^CC_2-G_2)+\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^2(\tau^CC_1-G_1)+\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^1(\tau^CC_0-G_0)\\[1.5em]B_0&=\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^3B_3+\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^3(\tau^CC_2-G_2)+\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^2(\tau^CC_1-G_1)+\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^1(\tau^CC_0-G_0)\end{aligned}B0​B0​B0​B0​​=1+r1​[1+r1​(B2​+τcC1​−G1​)+τcC0​−G0​]=1+r1​[1+r1​((1+r1​(B3​+τcC2​−G2​))+τcC1​−G1​)+τcC0​−G0​]=(1+r1​)3(B3​+τCC2​−G2​)+(1+r1​)2(τCC1​−G1​)+(1+r1​)1(τCC0​−G0​)=(1+r1​)3B3​+(1+r1​)3(τCC2​−G2​)+(1+r1​)2(τCC1​−G1​)+(1+r1​)1(τCC0​−G0​)​
Above, we singled out (11+r)3B3\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^3B_3(1+r1​)3B3​, so that we can see another pattern: (11+r)3(τCC2−G2)+(11+r)2(τCC1−G1)+(11+r)1(τCC0−G0)\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^3(\tau^CC_2-G_2)+\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^2(\tau^CC_1-G_1)+\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^1(\tau^CC_0-G_0)(1+r1​)3(τCC2​−G2​)+(1+r1​)2(τCC1​−G1​)+(1+r1​)1(τCC0​−G0​). This calls for a summator!

B0=(11+r)TBT+∑t=0T−1(11+r)t+1(τCCt−Gt)\begin{aligned}B_0&=\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^TB_T+\sum^{T-1}_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^{t+1}(\tau^CC_t-G_t)\end{aligned}B0​​=(1+r1​)TBT​+t=0∑T−1​(1+r1​)t+1(τCCt​−Gt​)​

Take out (11+r)1\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^1(1+r1​)1:

B0=(11+r)TBT+(11+r)1∑t=0T−1(11+r)t(τCCt−Gt)\begin{aligned}B_0&=\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^TB_T+\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^1\sum^{T-1}_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^{t}(\tau^CC_t-G_t)\end{aligned}B0​​=(1+r1​)TBT​+(1+r1​)1t=0∑T−1​(1+r1​)t(τCCt​−Gt​)​

Let T→∞T\to\inftyT→∞. From exercise: lim⁡T→∞BT=0\lim_{T\to\infty}B_T=0limT→∞​BT​=0

B0=(11+r)∑t=0T−1(11+r)t(τCCt−Gt)\begin{aligned}B_0&=\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)\sum^{T-1}_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^{t}(\tau^CC_t-G_t)\end{aligned}B0​​=(1+r1​)t=0∑T−1​(1+r1​)t(τCCt​−Gt​)​

From exercise: B0=0B_0=0B0​=0, and take out constant τC\tau^CτC out of the summator:
0=(11+r)τC∑t=0T−1(11+r)t(Ct−Gt)\begin{aligned}0&=\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)\tau^C\sum^{T-1}_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^{t}(C_t-G_t)\end{aligned}0​=(1+r1​)τCt=0∑T−1​(1+r1​)t(Ct​−Gt​)​

Multiply by (1+r)(1+r)(1+r):
0=τC∑t=0T−1(11+r)t(Ct−Gt)\begin{aligned}0&=\tau^C\sum^{T-1}_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^{t}(C_t-G_t)\end{aligned}0​=τCt=0∑T−1​(1+r1​)t(Ct​−Gt​)​

Separate the summator terms and account for consumer’s expectations. government has planned expenditures, so no expectations here. the government taxes not one individual but many so even if there is a change in let’s say one consumers income above or below expectation the government will plan its budget based on the taxes it expects to collect over many consumers. Also τC\tau^CτC is constant, so take it out of expectation and summator.
τCE0∑t=0T−1(11+r)tCt=∑t=0T−1(11+r)tGt\begin{aligned}\tau^CE_0\sum^{T-1}_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^tC_t&=\sum^{T-1}_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^{t}G_t\end{aligned}τCE0​t=0∑T−1​(1+r1​)tCt​​=t=0∑T−1​(1+r1​)tGt​​

i) RHS
Since {Gt}t=0∞={Gˉ,G‾,Gˉ,G‾,...}\left\{G_t\right\}^\infty_{t=0}=\left\{\bar{G},\underline{G},\bar{G},\underline{G},...\right\}{Gt​}t=0∞​={Gˉ,G​,Gˉ,G​,...} is given, we have:
RHS=∑t=0T−1(11+r)tGt=Gˉ+(11+r)1G‾+(11+r)2Gˉ+(11+r)3G‾+...=∑t=0∞(11+r)2t(Gˉ+11+rG‾)\begin{aligned}\text{RHS}=\sum^{T-1}_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^{t}G_t&=\bar{G}+\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^{1}\underline{G}+\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^{2}\bar{G}+\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^{3}\underline{G}+...\\[1.5em]&=\sum^\infty_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^{2t}\left(\bar{G}+\frac{1}{1+r}\underline{G}\right)\end{aligned}RHS=t=0∑T−1​(1+r1​)tGt​​=Gˉ+(1+r1​)1G​+(1+r1​)2Gˉ+(1+r1​)3G​+...=t=0∑∞​(1+r1​)2t(Gˉ+1+r1​G​)​

Remember convergence of an infinite geometric sequence: ∑t=0∞at=11−aif 0<a<1\sum^\infty_{t=0}a^t=\frac{1}{1-a}\qquad \text{if } 0<a<1t=0∑∞​at=1−a1​if 0<a<1!

∑t=0∞(11+r)2t=(11−(11+r)2)=(1(1+r)2(1+r)2−1(1+r)2)=(11+2r+r2(1+r)2−1(1+r)2)=12r+r2(1+r)2=(1+r)22r+r2\begin{aligned}\sum^\infty_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^{2t}&=\left(\frac{1}{1-\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^2}\right)\\[1.5em]&=\left(\frac{1}{\frac{(1+r)^2}{(1+r)^2}-\frac{1}{(1+r)^2}}\right)\\[1.5em]&=\left(\frac{1}{\frac{1+2r+r^2}{(1+r)^2}-\frac{1}{(1+r)^2}}\right)\\[1.5em]&=\frac{1}{\frac{2r+r^2}{(1+r)^2}}\\[1.5em]&=\frac{(1+r)^2}{2r+r^2}\end{aligned}t=0∑∞​(1+r1​)2t​=(1−(1+r1​)21​)=⎝⎛​(1+r)2(1+r)2​−(1+r)21​1​⎠⎞​=((1+r)21+2r+r2​−(1+r)21​1​)=(1+r)22r+r2​1​=2r+r2(1+r)2​​

Thus:
RHS=(1+r)22r+r2(Gˉ+11+rG‾)‾‾≡GX\begin{aligned}\text{RHS} &= \underline{\underline{\frac{(1+r)^2}{2r+r^2}\left(\bar{G}+\frac{1}{1+r}\underline{G}\right)}}\\[1.5em]&\equiv G_{X}\end{aligned}RHS​=2r+r2(1+r)2​(Gˉ+1+r1​G​)​​≡GX​​

We can define this RHS-function as some variable GXG_{X}GX​, because all terms are constants, so it doesn’t change over time.

ii) LHS
Use the per-period budget constraint At+1=(1+r)[At+Yt−(1+τc)Ct−Tt]A_{t+1}=(1+r)[A_t+Y_t-(1+\tau^c)C_t-T_t]At+1​=(1+r)[At​+Yt​−(1+τc)Ct​−Tt​]

We have that
T=0τC=constant\begin{aligned}T&=0\\\tau^C&=\text{constant}\end{aligned}TτC​=0=constant​

At+1=(1+r)At+(1+r)Yt−(1+r)(1+τc)CtA_{t+1}=(1+r)A_t+(1+r)Y_t-(1+r)(1+\tau^c)C_tAt+1​=(1+r)At​+(1+r)Yt​−(1+r)(1+τc)Ct​

Solve for CtC_tCt​:
(1+r)(1+τc)Ct=(1+r)At+(1+r)Yt−At+1Ct=(1+r)At+Yt(1+r)(1+τc)+At+1(1+r)(1+τc)=At+Yt1+τc+At+1(1+r)(1+τc)\begin{aligned}(1+r)(1+\tau^c)C_t&=(1+r)A_t+(1+r)Y_t-A_{t+1}\\[0.5em]C_t&=\frac{(1+r)A_t+Y_t}{(1+r)(1+\tau^c)}+\frac{A_{t+1}}{(1+r)(1+\tau^c)}\\[0.5em]&=\frac{A_t+Y_t}{1+\tau^c}+\frac{A_{t+1}}{(1+r)(1+\tau^c)}\end{aligned}(1+r)(1+τc)Ct​Ct​​=(1+r)At​+(1+r)Yt​−At+1​=(1+r)(1+τc)(1+r)At​+Yt​​+(1+r)(1+τc)At+1​​=1+τcAt​+Yt​​+(1+r)(1+τc)At+1​​​

Plug in for CtC_tCt​ in LHS:\text{LHS:}LHS:
LHS=τCE0∑t=0T−1(11+r)tCt=τC[E0∑t=0T−1(11+r)t(At+Yt1+τc+At+1(1+r)(1+τc))]\begin{aligned}\text{LHS}&=\tau^CE_0\sum^{T-1}_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^tC_t\\[0.5em]&=\tau^C\left[E_0\sum^{T-1}_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^t\left(\frac{A_t+Y_t}{1+\tau^c}+\frac{A_{t+1}}{(1+r)(1+\tau^c)}\right)\right]\end{aligned}LHS​=τCE0​t=0∑T−1​(1+r1​)tCt​=τC[E0​t=0∑T−1​(1+r1​)t(1+τcAt​+Yt​​+(1+r)(1+τc)At+1​​)]​

Intermission:
Split into three summators:
=τC[∑t=0∞(11+r)t(At1+τC)+∑t=0∞(11+r)t(Yt1+τC)+∑t=0∞At+1(1+r)(1+τC)]=\tau^C\left[\sum^\infty_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^t\left(\frac{A_t}{1+\tau^C}\right)+\sum^\infty_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^t\left(\frac{Y_t}{1+\tau^C}\right)+\sum^\infty_{t=0}\frac{A_{t+1}}{(1+r)(1+\tau^C)}\right]=τC[t=0∑∞​(1+r1​)t(1+τCAt​​)+t=0∑∞​(1+r1​)t(1+τCYt​​)+t=0∑∞​(1+r)(1+τC)At+1​​]
Take out A0A_0A0​ (and by doing so remember to shift the summator that you took the A0A_0A0​ out of by one period):
=τC[A01+τC⏟constant+∑t=0∞(11+r)t+1(At+11+τC)⏟goes to 0 by transversality+∑t=0∞(11+r)t(Yt1+τC)+∑t=0∞At+1(1+r)(1+τC)⏟goes to 0 by transversality]=τC[A01+τC+0+∑t=0∞(11+r)t(Yt1+τC)+0]=τC[A01+τC+∑t=0∞(11+r)t(Yt1+τC)]\begin{aligned}&=\tau^C\left[\underbrace{\frac{A_0}{1+\tau^C}}_\text{constant}+\underbrace{\sum^\infty_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^{t+1}\left(\frac{A_{t+1}}{1+\tau^C}\right)}_{\text{goes to 0 by transversality}}+\sum^\infty_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^t\left(\frac{Y_t}{1+\tau^C}\right)+\underbrace{\sum^\infty_{t=0}\frac{A_{t+1}}{(1+r)(1+\tau^C)}}_{\text{goes to 0 by transversality}}\right]\\[3.5em]&=\tau^C\left[{\frac{A_0}{1+\tau^C}}+0+\sum^\infty_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^t\left(\frac{Y_t}{1+\tau^C}\right)+0\right]\\[2.5em]&=\tau^C\left[\frac{A_0}{1+\tau^C}+\sum^\infty_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^t\left(\frac{Y_t}{1+\tau^C}\right)\right]\end{aligned}​=τC⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎡​constant1+τCA0​​​​+goes to 0 by transversalityt=0∑∞​(1+r1​)t+1(1+τCAt+1​​)​​+t=0∑∞​(1+r1​)t(1+τCYt​​)+goes to 0 by transversalityt=0∑∞​(1+r)(1+τC)At+1​​​​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎤​=τC[1+τCA0​​+0+t=0∑∞​(1+r1​)t(1+τCYt​​)+0]=τC[1+τCA0​​+t=0∑∞​(1+r1​)t(1+τCYt​​)]​

And rewrite a bit:
=τC[A0+∑t=0∞(11+r)tYt1+τC]=\tau^C\left[\frac{A_0+\sum^\infty_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^tY_t}{1+\tau^C}\right]=τC[1+τCA0​+∑t=0∞​(1+r1​)tYt​​]

In short, because of transversality, lim⁡t→∞(11+r)tAt=0\lim_{t\to\infty}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^tA_t=0limt→∞​(1+r1​)tAt​=0. In other words: aside from initial wealth all wealth added from now to infinity has to approach 0.

=τC(A0+E0∑t=0T−1(11+r)t(At+Yt1+τc+At+1(1+r)(1+τc)))=τC(A0+E0∑t=0T−1(11+r)tYt1+τC)\begin{aligned}&=\tau^C\left(A_0+E_0\sum^{T-1}_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^t\left(\frac{A_t+Y_t}{1+\tau^c}+\frac{A_{t+1}}{(1+r)(1+\tau^c)}\right)\right)\\[1.5em]&=\tau^C\left(\frac{A_0+E_0\sum^{T-1}_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^tY_t}{1+\tau^C}\right)\end{aligned}​=τC(A0​+E0​t=0∑T−1​(1+r1​)t(1+τcAt​+Yt​​+(1+r)(1+τc)At+1​​))=τC(1+τCA0​+E0​∑t=0T−1​(1+r1​)tYt​​)​

We set LHS and RHS equal, because government expenditure is financed by tax rate. We solve for τC\tau^CτC, to get the positive consumption tax τC\tau^CτC that does not distort the savings decision of the consumer.

LHS=RHSτC(A0+E0∑t=0T−1(11+r)tYt1+τC)=GXτC(A0+E0∑t=0T−1(11+r)tYt1+τC)−GX=0τC(A0+E0∑t=0T−1(11+r)tYt)−GX(1+τC)=0τC(A0+E0∑t=0T−1(11+r)tYt)−GX−τCGX=0τC(A0+E0∑t=0T−1(11+r)tYt)−τCGX=GXτC(A0+E0∑t=0T−1(11+r)tYt−GX)=GXτC=GXA0+E0∑t=0T−1(11+r)tYt−GX‾‾\begin{aligned}\text{LHS}=\text{RHS}\\[1.5em]\tau^C\left(\frac{A_0+E_0\sum^{T-1}_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^tY_t}{1+\tau^C}\right)&=G_{X}\\[1.5em]\tau^C\left(\frac{A_0+E_0\sum^{T-1}_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^tY_t}{1+\tau^C}\right)-G_{X}&=0\\[1.5em]\tau^C\left(A_0+E_0\sum^{T-1}_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^tY_t\right)-G_{X}(1+\tau^C)&=0\\[1.5em]\tau^C\left(A_0+E_0\sum^{T-1}_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^tY_t\right)-G_{X}-\tau^CG_X&=0\\[1.5em]\tau^C\left(A_0+E_0\sum^{T-1}_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^tY_t\right)-\tau^CG_X&=G_X\\[1.5em]\tau^C\left(A_0+E_0\sum^{T-1}_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^tY_t-G_X\right)&=G_X\\[1.5em]\tau^C=\underline{\underline{\frac{G_X}{A_0+E_0\sum^{T-1}_{t=0}\left(\frac{1}{1+r}\right)^tY_t-G_X}}}\end{aligned}LHS=RHSτC(1+τCA0​+E0​∑t=0T−1​(1+r1​)tYt​​)τC(1+τCA0​+E0​∑t=0T−1​(1+r1​)tYt​​)−GX​τC(A0​+E0​t=0∑T−1​(1+r1​)tYt​)−GX​(1+τC)τC(A0​+E0​t=0∑T−1​(1+r1​)tYt​)−GX​−τCGX​τC(A0​+E0​t=0∑T−1​(1+r1​)tYt​)−τCGX​τC(A0​+E0​t=0∑T−1​(1+r1​)tYt​−GX​)τC=A0​+E0​∑t=0T−1​(1+r1​)tYt​−GX​GX​​​​​=GX​=0=0=0=GX​=GX​​

PS1(2019) Q3: Natural Experiment Study of PIH

Assume that desired consumption is flat. On April 1st, 2018 a firm announced that it would increase wages of its employees from January 1st, 2019. Assume that consumption in April 2018 increased, stayed at this level until December 2018 and experienced a further increase in January 2019 and remained at the attained level afterwards.

Is this behavior in line with the predictions of the permanent income hypothesis? If your answer is
yes, explain intuitively why it should be like that. If your answer is no, what would be the predictions of the permanent income hypothesis and what could nevertheless rationalize such a
finding.

Solution:

  • the initial increase in consumption in April 2018 is in like with the PIH
  • the increase in January 2019 cannot be explained by the PIH
    • consumption growth does not react to predicted income changes, if these are expected
    • if the news about wage increase arrives on April 1st, 2018, the change in income will be expected/anticipated   ⟹  Δct+1≠0\implies \Delta c_{t+1} \ne0⟹Δct+1​​=0 where t=t+1t=t+1t=t+1 is April 2018
    • If then, expectations remain unchanged, consumption growth will stay unchanged
      • Δct+1=0\Delta c_{t+1}=0Δct+1​=0 if yt+1=E(yt+1)y_{t+1}=E(y_{t+1})yt+1​=E(yt+1​), true even if actual income differs from expected income
      • increase in January 2019 makes no sense in PIH terms
